description.narrative:
This project is building on the Irish Aid Grant through our OIE office. The current project is being implemented by CEDOVIP focusing on building strong institutions to respond to Violence Against Women and Girls(VAWG). It also seeks to challenge the negative attitudes and limited knowledge that perpetuate VAWG. This Oxfam Novib project will supplement the ongoing project with the partner. It will contribute to the same objectives as ongoing project i.e i) enhancing the capacity of relevant duty bearers on the existing policy and legislation on gender equality ii) improved knowledge and attitudes towards GBV iii) increased awareness and utilization of support structures that exist for GBV survivors This will specifically contribute to capacity building through training of the different structures health care workers, CFPU officers, referral network, opinion leaders, implementing partners. It will support project convenings by holding steering committee meetings with health care professionals, police and mentoring support for MEMPROW and AWARE for improved GBV response. Annual data collection will also be supported with this project
Their work aims to create change in the attitudes, behavior, and practices that perpetuate Violence Against Women and Girls (VAW/G). This work also aims at deepening knowledge and skills of the different institutions. Thus, they will coordinate all VAWG activities and will ensure a functional skilledreferral pathway on GBV

participating-org.narrative: CENTER FOR DOMESTIC VIOLENCE PREVEN CEDOVIP

Founded in 2003 Center for Domestic Violence Prevention (CEDOVIP )is committed to preventing violence against women and works withthose actors from various sectors to create a comprehensive prevention and response system in Uganda. CEDOVIP works with communities, institutions, civil society and the government, to promote the rights of women and girls so as to create safer, healthier, and happier relationships, homes and communities. The work aims to create change in the attitudes, behavior, and practices that perpetuate Violence Against Women and Girls (VAW/G) in Uganda.
CEDOVIP coordinated the successful advocacy for the passing of the Domestic Violence Act 2010 and is still committed to working with the law enforcing bodies to enable its implementation. CEDOVIP builds relationships and inspires institutions such as the Uganda Police Force and the Ministry of Health to accept technical support to streamline and formulate structures that define how the institution can effectively respond to VAW/G. For example, CEDOVIP has been given a key role in the police curriculum review process to support the Uganda Police Force to include GBV modules and change practice to strengthen service delivery for survivors of VAW/G.
OURGOAL Building a movement to prevent violence against women and girls in Uganda To accomplish this goal, CEDOVIP focuses on mobilizing communities to prevent and respond to VAW/G; strengthening prevention and response to VAW/G by civil society organizations, government, local institutions, and institutions of learning; and advocacy for better implementation of existing laws and policies, as well as for passage of new, more effective laws and policies.
OURVISION Existence of violence-free relationships OURMISSION To transformthe power imbalance in intimate relationships through awareness raising, collective visioning, and concerted efforts among community members
